cicognara-rails.title: Changed position to keep facets from spilling over into footer
Sorting by date is not working

comments.body:
When sorting by date (e.g. "sort by year, newest first") the system is sorting based on the `pub_date_sort` field in Solr. The exact sort clause is [pub_date_sort desc, title_sort asc](https://github.com/pulibrary/cicognara-rails/blob/main/app/controllers/catalog_controller.rb#L210). 

The results displayed to the user come in the correct order based on the `pub_date_sort` value stored in Solr, however, what we display to the user sometimes shows either *no date* or a *different date* than the one stored in Solr.

For example, item [2591](https://cicognara.org/catalog/2591) has a `pub_date_sort` in Solr of 1821 but the TEI file for this item has a date of 1819 and we display the 1819 date to the user. You can view these values here: https://cicognara.org/catalog/2591.json, look for fields `tei_date_display` and `pub_date_sort`.

To a user this record should be displayed along other items from 1819 but instead if shows mixed with records from 1821 because the `pub_date_sort` has the 1821 value. See screenshot below.

![cicognara_dates](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/568286/148289896-b598f393-1206-4b60-b489-3ae8f917f9c0.png)

Notice that when we display a record page (or a search result item) we are NOT using the data in Solr, instead we are using the pre-generated partials views under app/views/pages/catalogo. For example, for record 2591 we display the partial https://github.com/pulibrary/cicognara-rails/blob/main/app/views/pages/catalogo/_item_2591.html. Notice that this partial has the 1819 date.

We could probably re-generate the partials to include the `pub_date_sort` rather than the `tei_date_display` (or in addition to it?) but I am not sure of the ramifications of this.

Basically, it looks like the problem is that the display date and the data from the MARC records don't match. Maybe we should sort on `tei_date_display`, since that's pulled from the TEI like the displayed date?

The data in `tei_date_display' is a mess, sometimes it has values like ["A. 1541,"](https://cicognara.org/catalog/15.json) or ["1813 al 1818,"](https://cicognara.org/catalog/18.json) or [multiple values](https://cicognara.org/catalog/32.json). 

Plus it is stored but not indexed field.

@hectorcorrea OK, so it won't be as easy as that. But taking a look at the TEI, it does look like the overwhelming number of items have a four-digit year (or a range like `1813 al 1818`).  Could we update the indexer to parse the first 4-digit number into a new indexed field for sorting?

figgy.title: Add RasterSet fingerprinting to mosaic service
Provide raster visibility in titiler endpoint response

comments.body: How are we planning to use this visibility key? It's not clear to me what the use cases are here and how we plan to handle each.

I guess I was thinking, at a basic level we could IP restrict the data. The edge lambda would check if it's Princeton-only and then compare the client IP with a list of Princeton IP ranges. Reject if not in range.

I think I'd want to split out the use cases here and come up with some solutions for them. There's nothing really wrong with this, but I don't want to get too far down the line of supporting restricted datasets until we have open ones well supported. It's likely we'd need some form of callback to Figgy and I want to have a chance to think through the auth and caching pieces.

I get that, and I can put this PR in draft, but in my experience from the last few days, a callback to figgy on every tile call just isn't going to work. Far too slow for a good user experience. 

Also, from what I've seen, we really don't have many public raster datasets (hence the weird sample dataset that was provided). We're going to have to figure out the restricted data issue pretty soon IMO.

@eliotjordan Thank you. I just don't want to go too far down the restricted content path when we need to tighten up the easy path first. There's no guarantee we'll have the cycles to have a good "open" dataset path and still have time to do restricted ones, so I want to make sure we nail this and get the gotchas and then have a good sit down to properly architect restricted content when we know everything we can know about performant open content display.

Right, sorry. I confused myself with the lingo. Thanks for clarifying.
